terms.definition: One switch controls one lamp from one place.
A ceiling accessory that acts like a junction point and has three terminal groups: Loop (permanent live), Neutral, and Switched Live.
A live feed that stays live when the circuit is energised, even if the switch is OFF.
The live that only becomes live when the switch is ON, and feeds the lamp live.
Circuit Protective Conductor: the protective earth path that helps protective devices operate safely under fault conditions.
A coloured marker at the ends of a conductor to show its function (e.g., brown sleeving on a core used as live).

content.title: First: What You Actually See (no wiring yet)
content.content:
Rig-safety note (read this): This lesson is **conceptual** and for **training rigs only**. Do not open or work on real lighting circuits unless you are trained/supervised and the circuit is safely isolated and proven dead.

If you’ve never seen these parts before, start with the physical picture.

## A) What you see at a 3-plate ceiling rose
A typical 3-plate ceiling rose has **three separate terminal groups** (think: three labelled slots/buckets):

1) **Neutral group (N):** where neutrals join together (supply neutral + lamp neutral).
2) **Loop group (Permanent Live / Loop):** where permanent lives join together (the live feed(s) and the live that feeds the switch).
3) **Switched live group:** where the switched live return joins the lamp live.

You may also see an **earth/CPC terminal or connector** where all CPCs are joined.

## B) What you see at a one-way switch
A one-way switch typically has:
- **COM (Common):** the input (it receives the permanent live feed)
- **L1 (or “1”):** the output (it becomes live only when the switch is ON)
- an **earth terminal/connection point** (CPC must be terminated/connected as required on the rig)

## C) The single most important beginner rule
**The lamp live must NOT go into the Loop (permanent live) group.**
- Loop group = “always live when the circuit is on.”
- Lamp live must be “only live when the switch is on,” so it belongs in the **Switched live group**.

## D) Identification (why sleeving exists)
Sometimes a core colour doesn’t match its job (especially in switch-drop cables). **Any core used as live must be identified as live (brown) at the ends.**

content.title: Second: The Wire Journey (plain English)
content.content:
Now we connect the physical parts to the *story* of the electricity path.

## The golden rule
In this classic method, the **switch interrupts the live path**, not the neutral.

## 1) Permanent live journey (to the switch)
- The **live from the supply** arrives at the ceiling rose and terminates in the **Loop group**.
- From that same Loop group, a **live feed goes down to the switch** and lands on **COM**.

## 2) Switched live journey (back from the switch to the lamp)
- When the switch is ON, it connects **COM → L1**.
- The conductor on **L1** becomes the **switched live return**.
- That switched live return goes back up to the rose and terminates in the **Switched live group**.
- From that group it connects to the **lamp live**.

## 3) Neutral journey (lamp return path)
- Neutral does **not** go through the switch in this method.
- The supply neutral joins the lamp neutral in the **Neutral group** at the rose.

## 4) CPC journey (safety path)
- CPC must remain continuous through the circuit.
- On the rig: CPCs are joined and terminated/connected as required at the rose and switch point.

## Quick termination map (beginner version)
- **Rose Loop:** supply live + feed down to switch COM
- **Rose Neutral:** supply neutral + lamp neutral
- **Rose Switched Live:** return from switch L1 + lamp live
- **CPC:** joined/terminated at all points (rig rules)

content.title: Worked Example (I Do): Make a Termination Plan Before You Touch Anything
content.given: Training rig scenario: One ceiling rose, one one-way switch, one lamp. You have a supply feed to the rose, a switch-drop cable between rose and switch, and a lamp flex to the lamp holder.

steps.description: Name the four conductor roles you must account for.
steps.result: Permanent live (Loop), Switched live, Neutral, CPC

steps.description: Plan the rose terminations (which role goes to which terminal group).
steps.result: Loop group: supply live + feed to switch COM. Neutral group: supply neutral + lamp neutral. Switched live group: return from switch L1 + lamp live. CPCs: joined/terminated as required on rig.

steps.description: Plan the switch terminations (which role goes to which terminal).
steps.result: COM: permanent live feed from rose Loop. L1: switched live return back to rose Switched live group. CPC: terminated/connected as required.

steps.description: Apply the identification rule (where brown sleeving is needed).
steps.result: Any core used as live (feed to COM and return from L1) is identified brown at the terminations.

steps.description: Write a one-line plan note (so you can check your work).
steps.result: Plan: Loop→COM feed, L1 return→Switched Live→Lamp Live; neutrals in Neutral group; CPC continuous.

content.notes: Beginners win by planning first. If you can say the plan out loud, wiring becomes a simple matching exercise on the rig.

content.title: Pre-flight (Dead) Inspection Checklist — beginner-safe
content.content:
Before any meter tests, do a simple visual quality gate on the **dead** rig.

## PASS / SUSPICIOUS / STOP-AND-FIX
- **PASS:** looks neat and correct → OK to proceed to dead tests.
- **SUSPICIOUS:** something looks odd → fix/verify before metering (bad terminations can distort results).
- **STOP-AND-FIX:** unsafe/invalid → do not continue.

## Checklist (read top to bottom)
1) **No exposed copper** outside any terminal.
2) **No plastic-in:** insulation is not trapped under the terminal clamp.
3) **Sheath enters the accessory:** outer sheath is inside the point of entry (strain relief).
4) **Gentle tug test:** conductors are secure (do not yank).
5) **CPC present and managed:** CPCs are joined/terminated as required (none left floating).
6) **Brown identification present** on any core used as live at terminations (feed/return).

questions.hint: Think: visible copper or the wrong thing clamped.

questions.questionText: What does 'plastic-in' mean?
expectedAnswer: Insulation is clamped instead of copper
The terminal is gripping the insulation not the conductor
The copper isn’t properly inside the terminal

questions.questionText: Why should the cable sheath enter the accessory rather than stopping outside it?
expectedAnswer: So the cores are protected and supported
To reduce strain on inner cores
questions.hint: It protects and supports the inner cores.

questions.questionText: Why do we do pre-flight checks before any meter tests?
expectedAnswer: Because unsafe/poor terminations are dangerous and can also make test results unreliable
To catch faults before testing so results aren’t distorted
questions.hint: Two reasons: safety + valid test results.
